course.subject: MATH
course.name: Capstone Project in Pure Mathematics
course.description: This is a project-based course that provides students an opportunity to integrate and apply mathematical tools to analyze problems in pure mathematics. Specific topics will be chosen by the instructor. For MATH students in their fourth year of study only.
course.prerequisites: MATH 3121 OR MATH 3131
course.exclusions: MATH 4992, MATH 4993, MATH 4994, MATH 4999

reviews.author: TheodoreYuen
reviews.comment_content:
The Four professors will give 3 lectures each on the topic of their choice, then we will be broken into groups and work on our own projects that are related to one of the covered topics for the rest of the semester.

Topics:
Professor Yan: Tiling
Professor Zhu: Fourier Transform, Hankel Transform, and Generalisation
Professor Meng: Completion, Representation Theory, and Duality
Professor Chen: Algebraic geometry (?)

Kind of messy, good intention in that it's designed so that we can have more options for the final project, but in practice, it's not an enjoyable experience, to say the least
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Yan's and professor Meng's classes are pretty clear and well-organised.
Professor Zhu's classes are mostly just PowerPoint reading, not a very good idea for this topic.
Professor Chen's classes are just confusing and feel unorganised.

In addition, the arrangement for the final report submission and the homework for professor Chen's part is chaotic, the homework question was not posted until 2 days before the deadline, the instruction for the submission of the final report was unclear, and I suspect even the other 3 professors were confused about the arrangement
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 10%
Homework: 15%
Final Report: 45%
Presentation: 30%
Remarks: Not sure if this is accurate

Since there isn't any data released for the final report and presentation score, I can only speak from personal experience, and it does seem pretty lenient.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 homework issued by each of the 4 professors, they are not difficult, just go through the note, some basic understanding is needed but not demanding.

As for the final report, it depends on what your group choose to work on.

No need to worry about the presentation, just need to make sure you know what's in your report and you will be fine, the use of PowerPoint is optional, you can just screen share your final report and talk with it on screen
